importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The first Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine was announced on this date, marking the official start of the 2025 Nobel Prizes week.
The final prize of the year, the Economics Prize, is announced on this date, concluding the week-long announcement schedule.
The first Nobel Prizes were awarded in 1901, establishing a long-standing tradition of recognizing scientific and humanitarian achievements.
The Prize in Economic Sciences was established in 1968 by Sveriges Riksbank, expanding the Nobel Prizes to six categories.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: This week-long announcement period generates global media attention and public interest in science, peace, and human progress.
The formal award ceremonies occur on December 10, the anniversary of Alfred Nobel’s death, reinforcing the historical and symbolic continuity of the awards.

keyTakeAways: The Nobel Prizes are the most prestigious international awards, established by Alfred Nobel’s will in 1895, recognizing individuals who have conferred the greatest benefit to humankind.
The prizes are awarded annually in six categories: physics, chemistry, medicine, literature, peace, and economic sciences.

Each prize is awarded by a different institution: the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences for physics, chemistry, and economics; the Nobel Assembly at Karolinska Institutet for medicine; the Swedish Academy for literature; and the Norwegian Nobel Committee for peace.
The 2025 awards begin on October 6 with medicine and conclude on October 13 with the economics prize.
The nomination process is confidential, with experts, past winners, and academics submitting nominations by January 31, and decisions kept secret for 50 years.

The Peace Prize often reflects current global events, such as ongoing conflicts in Gaza and Ukraine, and recent controversies surrounding U.S. President Donald Trump’s claims of deserving the prize for ending wars.
Experts caution that political interference, such as that from the Trump administration, threatens academic freedom and the integrity of the Nobel process.

Previous laureates include Victor Ambros and Gary Ruvkun (2024 medicine), John Hopfield and Geoffrey Hinton (2024 physics), David Baker, Demis Hassabis, and John Jumper (2024 chemistry), Han Kang (2024 literature), Nihon Hidankyo (2024 peace), and Daron Acemoglu, Simon Johnson, and James Robinson (2024 economics).

summaryOfNewsArticle: The 2025 Nobel Prizes have officially begun with the announcement of the physiology or medicine prize for Mary Brunkow, Fred Ramsdell, and Shimon Sakaguchi, recognizing their discoveries in peripheral immune tolerance with implications for cancer and autoimmune disease treatment. This marks the start of a week-long announcement period ending on October 13, during which prizes in physics, chemistry, literature, peace, and economics will be revealed. The article outlines the history, institutions, and nomination process of the Nobel Prizes, emphasizing their global significance in recognizing scientific and humanitarian contributions. It also highlights the controversy surrounding U.S. President Donald Trump’s claims of deserving the Peace Prize, noting that experts and institutions caution against such claims due to the prize’s focus on enduring peace and institutional work, not political self-promotion. The article underscores the importance of academic freedom and the integrity of the Nobel process, especially amid political interference.
